message_1:
Suppose we want to study the survival rates of a certain type of machine. We have data on 50 machines, and we know the time (in months) each machine functioned correctly before it failed. The data set is:
            
            24, 30, 31, 34, 35, 36, 38, 39, 41, 42, 43, 47, 49, 51,
            52, 53, 53, 54, 56, 58, 58, 59, 60, 60, 62, 62, 63, 64,
            64, 65, 65, 66, 68, 69, 70, 72, 72, 73, 73, 74, 75, 76, 77,
            78, 78, 82, 85, 87, 91, 111.

What is the probability that a randomly selected machine will fail after at least 50 months of operation?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected machine will fail after at least 50 months of operation, we first need to count the number of machines that failed after 50 months or more. 

From the given data set, we can see that the following machines failed after at least 50 months:

51, 52, 53, 53, 54, 56, 58, 58, 59, 60, 60, 62, 62, 63, 64, 64, 65, 65, 66, 68, 69, 70, 72, 72, 73, 73, 74, 75, 76, 77, 78, 78, 82, 85, 87, 91, 111

There are a total of 37 machines that failed after at least 50 months.

Now, we can find the probability by dividing the number of machines that failed after at least 50 months by the total number of machines:

Probability = (Number of machines that failed after at least 50 months) / (Total number of machines)
Probability = 37 / 50
Probability = 0.74

So, the probability that a randomly selected machine will fail after at least 50 months of operation is 0.74 or 74%.
